column1: Here is a 64 word summary:\n\nIpswich Town beat AZ Alkmaar to win the UEFA Cup in 1981. The team, including Terry Butcher, won the first leg 3-0 at home before losing the second leg 4-2 in Holland. Butcher recently cycled 260 miles to Holland with a charity team commemorating the victory and raising money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

Storms Desmond, Eva, Frank, and Gertrude caused severe flooding in Hawick, Jedburgh, Newcastleton, and Peebles in the area. The full cost of repairs has not been calculated, but the council will receive support under the Bellwin Scheme. However, the council must contribute 0.2% of its net revenue budget, about £508,000. A report outlined 240 repair projects needed, not including further work below water lines on bridges.

Here is a 64 word summary:\n\nThomas Cook Airlines will operate weekly flights between Glasgow and Las Vegas from May to October 2015 using Airbus A330 aircraft. This follows successful one-off flights in recent years. The airline also announced additional flights to Tunisia in summer 2015. Glasgow Airport welcomed the new Las Vegas route, the first regular service between Scotland and Las Vegas, referring to it as excellent news which further strengthens its long-haul offering.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nEngland are in pot one for the Euro 2016 draw with Wales and Northern Ireland in pot four. Republic of Ireland could be in pot three or four depending on other results. Potential group is England, Italy, Czech Republic and Wales/Northern Ireland. Seedings are based on UEFA rankings. Other top seeds are Spain, France, Germany, Portugal and Belgium. Playoff draw takes place Sunday with Bosnia, Ukraine, Sweden and Hungary seeded and Ireland, Denmark, Norway and Slovenia possible opponents in November playoffs. Finals draw is 12 December.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nDamon Smith denies intending to endanger life with an improvised explosive device containing ball bearings on a London Underground train. He admits a bomb hoax. Police found the device after Smith exited the train. He has Asperger's, interest in weapons. He's not an extremist but reads Quran sometimes. He activated a timer on the device and later searched for news about the incident. The trial continues.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nMansfield District Council debated the controversial £250m Lindhurst housing development scheme despite over 140 objections. The planning committee was split in a 5-5 vote with the chairman casting the deciding vote in favor. Protesters shouted "shame" at the approval. The Lindhurst Group said the 1,700 home development with a school and other facilities would bring 4,000 jobs, but objections remain over loss of countryside, congestion and delivering promised benefits. The council's independent member wanted the secretary of state to review the contentious decision made on a casting vote.

Here is a 51 word summary of the text:\n\nThe UN says Europe has the worst record globally for discarding fish catches. Almost a quarter of all catches in Europe are thrown back into the ocean dead because they are not the desired species. This is according to a recent Newsround story.

Here is a 64 word summary:\n\nHP acquired WebOS from Palm in 2011 but was unable to recoup its investment. LG has now acquired WebOS to power its next generation of smart TVs. WebOS was originally created for smartphones and tablets but has struggled against competitors like Android. The deal gives LG the WebOS source code and engineers. HP is retaining WebOS patents and connectivity technology. LG sees WebOS as a good fit for TVs and the acquisition may mark a return to WebOS's smartphone roots as its web technology is well suited for mobile apps.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nU's Joe Pigott equalized in the 89th minute after Ipswich lost the ball to cancel out Andre Dozzell's opener. Manager McCarthy was furious, saying conceding the late goal was "unforgivable" and that he doesn't tolerate "that garbage". He pointed to several late conceded goals last season that cost Ipswich points and a playoff spot. McCarthy blasted his team's performance in the preseason friendly.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nTests on Jane Austen's glasses at the British Library show her eyesight deteriorated over time, likely due to arsenic poisoning. The three pairs of glasses increased in strength from +1.75 to +5.0, indicating Austen would have struggled to read or write by the time she died at 41. Curator Sandra Tuppen suggests Austen may have been accidentally poisoned by arsenic, which was used in medications she took for rheumatism. The glasses were examined using a lens meter, and optometrists are invited to offer opinions on the poisoning theory.

Here is a 64-word summary of the text:\n\nThe Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby announced he hopes to fix the date of Easter Sunday so that it falls on the same day for both Western and Eastern churches within 5-10 years. He is in talks with Catholic and Orthodox leaders about this proposal, which aims to end the variability of Easter's date that is currently determined by the lunar cycle. A fixed date has been attempted since the 10th century but not achieved due to disagreements between churches. Easter is Christianity's most important festival as it celebrates Jesus Christ's resurrection.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nThe latest April survey by Ulster Bank showed a modest deterioration in Northern Ireland's private sector business conditions, with declines in output and new orders. Manufacturing was a bright spot with growth in output and orders. However, retailers reported the sharpest drop in sales since May 2012 and construction activity fell sharply. Despite weakness, firms continued hiring staff rapidly across most sectors. The new Conservative government's fiscal plans and policies will affect all economic sectors.

Here is a 47-word summary of the text:\n\nThe UK Independence Party (UKIP) shop in Penarth, Wales has faced opposition since opening in November. UKIP now invites "anarchist friends" to throw eggs at posters of Nigel Farage and candidate John Rees-Evans. A UKIP spokesman said no eggs have been thrown at the posters so far.

Here is a 63 word summary of the text:\n\nWindsor's Theatre Royal was evacuated on Tuesday evening during the opening night of One Man, Two Guvnors due to flash flooding. Water poured into the auditorium from the back of the building during a heavy rainstorm. The theatre plans to continue performances on Wednesday after drying out. Audience members described water flowing towards the stage before the evacuation. The play is part of Windsor Repertory Company's 201st anniversary festival. The theatre's director said they had not experienced flooding like this before despite being open for 100 years.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nSince independence from Britain in 1970, Fiji has experienced political instability due to tensions between indigenous Fijians and ethnic Indians. Military leader Frank Bainimarama seized power in a 2006 coup and was elected prime minister in 2014 after championing equal rights. Media freedoms have been restricted since 2012. Fiji's history includes periods of British rule, coups in 1987 and 2000, and the election of an ethnic Indian PM in 1999 who was quickly overthrown.

Here is a 62-word summary of the text:\n\nThe pass rate dropped markedly in Bihar, India's school exams after measures were taken to curb cheating. However, a student who thought political science was cooking and another who excelled in science but failed a basic chemistry question cast doubt. The state has now suspended their results along with 12 others and will retest them with interviews and handwriting checks to verify if they actually took the exams themselves.

Here is a 64-word summary of the text:\n\nAfter losing an appeal, Manchester City Council evicted a protest camp of around 30 homeless people from St Peter's Square. The demonstrators had been there since mid-April to highlight issues like temporary housing and homelessness. Police and bailiffs broke up the camp on Tuesday morning. Some protesters left peacefully but others resisted. The council said the camp had caused vandalism, fighting, and cost over £88,000. The demonstrators have now set up another camp in St Anne's Square about half a mile away.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nTwo pieces of debris likely from missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 were found separately in Mozambique and flown to Australia for analysis. The finds support drift modeling of how debris could be carried by ocean currents. MH370 vanished in March 2014 with 239 aboard while flying from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. The plane's fate remains a mystery. Only one confirmed piece of MH370 debris has been found so far. Analysis concluded the Mozambique debris is almost certainly from MH370. This shows the ongoing deep-sea search in the southern Indian Ocean is focused on the right area, though 10,000 sq km remain to be searched. The countries involved say they will end the search once the area is fully scanned unless significant new evidence arises.

Here is a 62-word summary of the text:\n\nThe RMT union plans two more strike days in July in its dispute with ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour urged the transport minister to resolve the stalemate. The government said the minister engaged both sides to find a solution and called for meaningful discussion. The RMT opposes driver-only trains; ScotRail said most customers already travel in driver-only trains. The government said its committee met to minimize passenger disruption and advised checking ScotRail's website before traveling.

The Cavaliers defeated the Warriors in game 3 to trail 2-1 in the NBA finals series after opening with two losses. Kyrie Irving scored 30 points for Cleveland while Steph Curry had just 19 for Golden State. Cleveland was more aggressive according to LeBron James after Steve Kerr said the Warriors were not ready to play. Game 4 is also in Cleveland on Friday after the Warriors beat the Cavaliers in last year's Finals.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nEllie Goulding's Burn reached number one in the UK singles chart this week, selling 40,000 more copies than its closest rival. Lady Gaga's Applause entered the chart at number five. In the album chart, Britain's Got Talent winners Richard and Adam Johnson held the top spot for a third week with their debut album The Impossible Dream. Rudimental climbed to number two, while Imagine Dragons stayed at three. White Lies had the highest new entry at four with Big TV.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nHighland Council in Scotland avoided £1.3 million in planned budget cuts but made other savings including changing sickness policies and school energy incentives. A proposal to cut senior councillor pay was defeated. SNP opposed cuts to services for the vulnerable which the independent councillors had proposed. Councils across Scotland reluctantly accepted the government's funding deal as the continued council tax freeze pressures budgets, forcing Highland Council to make cuts leading to job losses and reduced services.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nReverend Barry Trayhorn was dismissed from volunteering at chapel services at HMP Littlehey after reading a Bible passage condemning homosexuality to prisoners in 2014. He told an employment tribunal he focused on teachings about sin and did not believe the faith should be altered to suit modern views on sexual ethics. Complaints were made by gay prisoners about the Bible reading and also about his gardening work. He claims he was forced out due to his Christian beliefs and is suing the justice secretary for unfair dismissal.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nThe independent immigration inspector said the Home Office needs to improve handling of "overstayers"- those refused leave to stay in the UK. The report found inaccuracies in contractor Capita's records, including overestimating departures. However, the overall number of overstayers is largely unchanged. The inspector said significant improvements are needed in monitoring and enforcement to reduce irregular migration. The immigration minister accepted recommendations but said government changes are having a positive impact.

Here is a 64-word summary of the text:\n\nThe My Dentist practice in Dolgellau, Wales will close on March 31st leaving the town with only one private practice. The NHS practice has been unable to recruit a permanent dentist for two years despite efforts. The deputy mayor said more needs to be done to get dentists to rural areas. My Dentist's clinical director cited a shortage of dentists in rural Wales with long-term vacancies. The local health board intends to re-commission dental services as soon as possible but there will likely be a gap before new services are in place. The health board is exploring options for short-term support from other practices and urgent care clinics.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nLiam Day, 26, went missing after apparently climbing alone near Durlston Country Park on Tuesday. An extensive search by police and coastguard began Wednesday but was suspended. His partner, Emily Brown, posted on Facebook that he likely won't return. Climbing equipment was found west of Anvil Point on Wednesday. Police are appealing for information from anyone who saw a man climbing in the area and say enquiries are ongoing.

Here is a 62-word summary of the text:\n\nJim McGuinness must devise a strategy for Donegal to combat Dublin's attacking style in the upcoming All-Ireland football semi-final. McGuinness says the tactical game will come down to the players, not the managers. He trusts his players to execute the game plan and make decisions on the field. McGuinness is unconcerned about Donegal being underdogs, as they were in their 2012 championship run. He remains focused on preparing his team properly rather than public perception.

Here is a 62-word summary of the text:\n\nA report by High Fliers found that in 2015, around 1,000 UK graduates turned down job offers at the last minute, leaving employers scrambling for replacements. This occurred even as the number of graduates hired rose 3.3% and starting salaries held steady at around £30,000. The report indicates that top graduates are increasingly selective and receiving multiple job offers from leading employers competing for the most skilled graduates.

A man suffered head and leg injuries after falling onto subway tracks at Twickenham station in London on Friday night as thousands of rugby fans were leaving nearby Twickenham Stadium following England's World Cup victory over Fiji. The man was hit by an oncoming train around 11pm. He was treated at the scene before being taken to St George's Hospital. His injuries are not believed to be life threatening. The station was temporarily evacuated during the incident. British Transport Police are investigating how the man fell onto the tracks. Train services were briefly suspended but later resumed.

Here is a 63 word summary of the text:\n\nMalta is an island nation in the Mediterranean with a long history of foreign rule. Strategically located between Europe and North Africa, it was successively occupied by various powers. Now an independent republic, Malta has developed into a leading trading hub. Tourism is the main industry. Malta suffered heavy bombing in World War 2 but was awarded the George Cross for bravery. It became independent from Britain in 1964 and joined the EU in 2004.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nJean-Marc Vallee's new tragicomedy Demolition starring Jake Gyllenhaal premiered at the Toronto Film Festival. Vallee praised Gyllenhaal's versatile performance. This is Vallee's third consecutive film at TIFF after Dallas Buyers Club and Wild. Michael Moore's satire Where to Invade Next also had its world premiere. TIFF is seen as the start of awards season, with past People's Choice winners like 12 Years a Slave going on to win Best Picture Oscars.

Here is a 64-word summary of the text:\n\nThe Belfast Telegraph reports on a boy injured in a petrol bomb attack who had previously battled a brain condition. The Irish News says five Orange Halls were awarded grants from a controversial Stormont scheme after applying as cultural groups. It also reports on a Tyrone boy fighting epilepsy in the US with cannabis oil. The News Letter says a prosecution decision on a suspect linked to the Kingsmills massacre by a palm print is expected within two weeks. The long-delayed inquest was put on hold last year over the palm print development.

Here is a 62 word summary of the text:\n\nA survey of 1000 UK adults by Action on Hearing Loss showed that many listen to music at unsafe volumes for prolonged periods, raising their risk of tinnitus. One-third would ignore volume limits on players. The charity warns that tinnitus can severely impact quality of life and that noise exposure can trigger it. DJ Paul Oakenfold supports their awareness campaign, urging music lovers to use ear defenders at concerts and keep volume lower on devices. He notes that noise-cancelling headphones also reduce risks.

France took the lead over the United States in the mixed team event at the Hopman Cup as Richard Gasquet beat Jack Sock in the men's match. Coco Vandeweghe leveled for the US by beating Kristina Mladenovic in the women's tie. Ultimately, Gasquet and Mladenovic won the decisive doubles match to give France the victory, their second Hopman Cup title and first since 2014. Great Britain was eliminated in the group stage.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nEddie Jones says he can feel the long-standing rivalry towards England as they prepare to face Ireland at Twickenham. The Australian says everyone hates England but he will be committed to the team. Jones sees Manu Tuilagi's future at inside centre for England once fully fit. England are top of the Six Nations with France on points difference. Jones praises his players but says they are a work in progress. He expects Ireland to kick a lot and concedes it has worked for them in the past.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nNew figures show paramedics in Scotland treated about 12,000 people who were severely intoxicated in a 6 month period. The data reveals alcohol is a factor in over half of weekend ambulance callouts. The problem is most acute in Greater Glasgow. The situation diverts resources from other patients and frustrates paramedics. Though the government is taking action on alcohol misuse, officials and experts say individuals must take personal responsibility for reckless drinking which taxes emergency services.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nThe Northern Ireland government has launched a new strategy called 'Enabling Success' to reduce economic inactivity, which is higher than the UK average. The voluntary program will target people with health conditions, disabilities, lone parents and carers to provide support so they can participate in the workforce. The goal is to raise employment levels above the UK average by 2030 to boost economic competitiveness and productivity.

Donald Trump criticized John McCain, saying that McCain was only considered a war hero because he was captured as a prisoner of war in Vietnam. Trump stated that he prefers people who were not captured. McCain was held for over 5 years after his plane was shot down in the Vietnam War, while Trump avoided service. Trump's comments prompted widespread criticism from Republicans. McCain's daughter and many of Trump's rivals attacked his remarks.

Here is a 63 word summary of the text:\n\nCanadian author WP Kinsella, best known for his baseball-themed novel Shoeless Joe which was adapted into the 1989 film Field of Dreams, died on Friday in a doctor-assisted death. Kinsella published over 30 works across various genres and was awarded the Order of Canada. After a car crash injury, he lost interest in fiction but resumed writing before his death - his final work Russian Dolls will be released next year.

Máiría Cahill won a by-election to fill a vacant Irish senate seat. She previously accused the IRA of raping her at 16 and forcing her silence. The man she accused was acquitted. She no longer considers herself a republican due to past involvement with a dissident group. After her election, she pledged to work for abuse victims' rights and young jobseekers. She was the favorite and won the most votes out of 4 candidates.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nChildLine has launched a Fight Against Porn Zombies campaign in response to calls from 12-13 year old boys worried about their porn usage. The charity's poll of 700 kids found 1 in 5 were shocked by explicit images. One boy said porn made him view girls differently and fear he may not marry. Another felt porn led him to sexually objectify girls. The NSPCC says society must address this issue affecting thousands of youth.

Mariner Street car park in Swansea will be replaced with a 22-storey, 725-bedroom student accommodation tower containing amenities like a nightclub and gym. It will be the city's second tallest building after Meridian Quay. Construction on the project, which aims to meet growing student housing demand from Swansea University and Trinity Saint David, is expected to start this year and finish in 2018. The development is seen as supporting High Street's regeneration.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nTorrential rain from remnants of Cyclone Debbie caused widespread flooding in the Australian states of Queensland and New South Wales. Numerous towns were inundated as rivers broke their banks, washing away roads, bringing down trees, and leaving tens of thousands without power. Evacuations were ordered in some areas while others used surfboards to traverse flooded streets. Brisbane and coastal communities suffered damage with insurers still assessing the full impact. A bull shark was even spotted in flood waters. Fortunately, the storm system has now moved offshore.

Here is a 63 word summary of the text:\n\nAmerican Airlines experienced a software glitch that caused iPads used by pilots and co-pilots to stop working, forcing some flights to return to the gate to fix the issue. The iPads replaced paper flight plans in 2013, saving over $1 million in fuel per year. Other airlines have also switched to electronic flight bags, providing benefits like reduced flight prep time and real-time updates. American Airlines uses Boeing's FliteDeck app for its iPads. The glitch caused some disruption but flights were able to continue after accessing wifi or printing paper backup.

Here is a 56 word summary of the text:\n\nGirish Pote was convicted in 2013 for murdering his wife Madhuvanti Pathak in Thane, a Mumbai suburb. He chopped her body into pieces and called relatives to confess before they informed police. Although life terms in India generally end after 14 years, the judge sentenced Pote to remain in jail for life due to the brutal nature of the crime. The couple had been fighting over money and because Pathak wanted to return to France where she held a passport.

Here is a 64-word summary of the text:\n\nBradford Council has drawn up plans for a clockwise one-way gyratory along East Parade, Hanover Street and Cavendish Street to combat the town's growing congestion problem. The plans, which will be displayed at the Airedale shopping centre on 11 and 13 June, aim to urgently address Bradford's traffic issues.

Here is a 57 word summary of the text:\n\n23-year-old Thorpe has made seven appearances this season for Rotherham United, last playing on November 7th in a 5-2 defeat by Ipswich. The former Manchester United youth player could make his debut for Bradford City against Millwall on Saturday. Bradford are currently 7th in League One, outside the playoff positions on goal difference.

A radio presenter impersonated Carles Puigdemont and called Mariano Rajoy's office, pretending to be the Catalan leader. Rajoy spoke to the fake Puigdemont and eagerly agreed to meet soon. When the presenter revealed it was a prank call, Rajoy said it was not serious but took the joke well. Rajoy and the real Puigdemont are at odds over Catalan independence. The prank call joins other examples like Tony Blair in 1998 and Fidel Castro in 2004 falling for impersonators.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nBaroness Williams faced criticism in the House of Lords over the £1 hourly rate paid to immigration detainees for voluntary work inside detention centers. She argued the work helps relieve boredom but opponents claim the low pay saves firms that run the centers hundreds of thousands monthly compared to paying staff minimum wage. Despite pressing from peers, Lady Williams maintained the main beneficiaries are the detainees themselves. The pay rate is currently under review with a report expected by year's end.

Here is a 63 word summary of the text:\n\nThe Walter Scott Prize shortlist has been narrowed down to seven novels that transport readers to different times and places. The contenders offer historical insights and compelling characters. The judges praised the varied selection and lively debate to decide the winner, who will be announced at the Borders Book Festival and receive £25,000. The shortlist includes acclaimed authors like Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, and Rose Tremain.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nBangladesh need 33 runs to seal their first Test win against England but have only two wickets left. Broad said it has been a fantastic game to play in and Bangladesh have shown great skill. He added that England have shown character and will come out fighting tomorrow. The match has already set a record for most reviews in a Test. Broad said it has been tense with a lot of passion from both teams. The match will resume tomorrow with England hoping to take early wickets while Bangladesh chase victory.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nMembers of the University of Aberdeen's medical school voted to strike over job security concerns. The university expressed disappointment and said they made arrangements to prevent exam disruption. The union questioned if the redundancy process was discriminatory as the four affected staff were Asian. The university denied discrimination and said the four were offered alternative roles, so compulsory redundancies were avoided. They emphasized their equal opportunities policies.

Here is a 57-word summary of the text:\n\nJay Brenton Liptrot, 43, owned a property in Prestatyn, Wales where five people died in a fire in October 2012. Lee-Ann Shiers, 20, her partner Liam Timbrell, 23, their son Charlie, 15 months, Ms Shiers' nephew Bailey, 4, and niece Skye, 2, perished. Melanie Smith was jailed for at least 30 years for starting the fire during a dispute over a shared hallway. Mr. Liptrot appeared in court but did not enter a plea; he will appear again in May.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nThe incident happened at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay. Police Scotland described it as a "disgraceful incident". A 34-year old man was expected to appear at Aberdeen Sheriff Court regarding the incident, but he was freed from custody pending further inquiries by the Crown Office.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nA new report called "Read On. Get On." says children who don't learn to read well by age 11 are less likely to get good qualifications or pursue higher education. The report aims to have all 11-year-olds reading well within a generation. Organizations like Save the Children want parents reading to kids for 10 minutes daily. They say 40% of low-income families own fewer than 10 children's books. Reading to toddlers makes them more likely to become keen readers themselves. The report says 220,000 Scottish children live in poverty, and that number may rise. The groups want every child given an equal chance to learn to read well.

The 30-year-old Martinelli signed with the Belfast Giants in 2016 and is staying for another season along with 28-year-old Mark Garside. Both players have helped the Giants win championships in the past, including Garside's recent World Championship gold medal. Head coach Adam Keefe praised both veterans, saying they are key parts of the team and will help in the chase for more trophies this season.
Rasmus Barlow, 16, was reported missing by his father on Monday. His body was later found and his death is not being treated as suspicious. Police are supporting his family.

Here is a 62 word summary of the text:\n\nRegina Hungerford, a 55-year-old teacher, was accused of striking a 17-year-old student when she lost her temper over his classroom music listening. Though she denied intentional contact, an education council ruled she likely made unacceptable physical contact by slamming a notebook on his desk. The panel found her in breach of teaching principles and said her conduct fell short of professional standards, undermining public trust, though the student's behavior was difficult. The council will decide later whether to strike her from the teaching register.

Big brands, charities, public figures, and companies are using the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou to promote products, raise awareness, and celebrate Star Wars Day on May 4th. Brands like British Museum and Heathrow Airport make creative posts referencing Star Wars characters and ships. Mark Hamill and James Earl Jones join in the fun by posting Star Wars themed photos. Overall, #MayThe4thBeWithYou has become a popular way to engage with Star Wars fans globally.

Here is a 63-word summary of the text:\n\nA group of retired generals and admirals declared Republican nominee Donald Trump has the temperament to be commander-in-chief. Trump called their support a great honor. Meanwhile, he dismissed claims of impropriety over a political donation to a Florida official who had considered investigating Trump University. Despite making support for the military a campaign issue, Trump has drawn criticism from some military members, notably involving a spat with a Muslim-American soldier's family. Both Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton will participate in a national security forum on Wednesday.

Here is a 56-word summary of the text:\n\n21-year-old Callum Harriott joined Barnsley last summer from QPR after their promotion to the Championship, but made just 7 league appearances. He briefly played on loan at Colchester from QPR in 2014-15, featuring 6 times. The left-sided player signed a one-year contract with a 12-month option at John McGreal's Colchester team.

Here is a 58 word summary of the text:\n\nPhillip Pullman is releasing a new trilogy called The Book of Dust, which is a companion series to his bestselling His Dark Materials trilogy. The first novel in the new series will be published in October 2017, though the title is not yet known. The new books will focus on Lyra Belacqua's life, starting when she is a baby through age 20. Pullman's original His Dark Materials trilogy, featuring Lyra, sold over 17.5 million copies and was translated into 40 languages.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nA safety poster by the American Red Cross depicting more black children as "not cool" and more white children as "cool" sparked backlash on social media for being racist. The Red Cross apologized, saying it was not their intent to offend anyone, and removed the poster from their website. The Salida Pool and Recreation Department where the poster was displayed also apologized. Despite the apologies, the reactions online have continued.

Here is a 64 word summary of the text:\n\nWinkelman says Robinson will remain as Milton Keynes Dons manager next season despite the club's relegation from the Championship. Robinson, the third longest serving manager in English football, had previously expressed doubts about staying. Though mistakes were made after promotion, Winkelman trusts Robinson, who already has experience gaining promotion from League One. Both agree more pressure comes with Milton Keynes becoming a bigger club, and Winkelman is excited for the challenge of being a big club in League One next season.

Here is a 62 word summary of the text:\n\nJames Cosmo and former Dr Who star Karen Gillan have been named honorary patrons of the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). Cosmo has starred in films like Braveheart while Gillan has turned to directing. EIFF artistic director Mark Adams said they were thrilled to add the two Scottish stars. Both actors expressed being honored and privileged to take on the patron roles, with Gillan noting she moved to Edinburgh as a teenager to study acting and has a creative connection to the city.

Here is a 63 word summary of the text:\n\nDanny Rose recently said in an interview that he felt underpaid at Tottenham and that the club needed to sign big name players. He has now apologized for the comments, saying the timing was "ill-judged". Manager Mauricio Pochettino has forgiven Rose and says he still has a future at the club. Rose will miss Tottenham's next game with a knee injury. Right-back Kieran Trippier also has an ankle injury but it is not as bad as initially feared and he is expected to recover quickly.

Here is a 64-word summary of the text:\n\nThe International Ski Federation banned British violinist Vanessa Vanakorn, who competed for Thailand under her father's name at the 2014 Sochi Olympics, for allegedly helping manipulate race results to qualify for the Games. Vanakorn finished last in the Giant Slalom. She has appealed her ban to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, calling it "nonsensical". An investigation found Vanakorn and Thai officials manipulated four pre-Olympic qualification races in Slovenia to ensure her Olympic berth.

Here is a 64-word summary of the text:\n\nMacclesfield Town beat Eastleigh 1-0 in their League Two match. Rhys Browne scored the only goal for Macclesfield in the 7th minute. Eastleigh had chances to equalize but hit the post and had a goal disallowed for offside. Both teams made multiple substitutions in the second half but the score remained 1-0 to Macclesfield at full time.

Warner Bros TV has been unable to reach new salary agreements with the cast of The Big Bang Theory. Production may be delayed if deals are not reached soon. The main cast currently earn $325,000 per episode but are seeking up to $1 million. If successful, they would become the highest paid TV actors in the US.

Alexander Worth was killed in a car crash on an access road between Newlyns and Lodge Farms in North Warnborough. The driver, Matthew Cobden, appeared in court and was released on unconditional bail. The case will go to Winchester Crown Court in July. The judge expressed sympathy to Alexander's family, noting he had also lost a brother in a traffic accident.

Refugees speak at a gathering in Wales, calling for action to resettle Syrian refugees in the UK. The Welsh Refugee Council welcomes the UK's commitment to resettle 20,000 Syrians. Demonstrations are held across Wales. A minister describes the crisis as a serious human-made disaster. The Welsh Government will hold a summit on the crisis as local authorities ask for help with costs of resettling refugees.

Here is a 63 word summary of the text:\n\nJhon Jairo Velasquez, nicknamed Popeye, was Pablo Escobar's top hitman and confessed to killing 300 people. He claimed involvement in up to 3,000 murders in the 1980s and 1990s. He provided evidence against an ex-justice minister convicted of ordering the killing of a rival. Velasquez was released from prison after two decades to start a four year probation period. He left under police escort due to risks outside jail. Colombia is divided on his early release - some insist he hasn't paid for his crimes, while others say after 20 years in jail it's time to give him a second chance.
